task_summary: Detect the T-shaped block, approach and align the circular tool, then execute repeated leftward pushes to drive the block into the target outline, and retreat.

task_long_description.overview: A fixed tabletop scene shows a red T-shaped block and a blue T-shaped outline that marks the goal region. A UR-style arm with a circular end-effector must push the block into the outline. The behavior first perceives the block and target, approaches from above with a small safety offset, aligns yaw for a side push, and performs three short pushes to translate the block toward the goal. After motion, the robot retreats to clear the workspace. The plan assumes moderate friction and uses short timeouts and precise alignment.
preconditions: Workspace clear around the block and target
Camera view contains both block and target outline
stepwise_plan: Move above the block with small vertical offset
Set tool yaw to 90° for side push
Approach and align precisely on block edge
success_criteria: Block’s pose overlaps the target outline within visual tolerance
No collisions with robot body or table edge
Robot retreats to a safe standoff
failure_and_recovery: If detection fails, rescan within action timeout
If alignment drifts, re-approach and align
If push stalls, repeat short pushes or increase approach distance on next attempt
task_long_description.termination: Terminate when pushes and retreat complete; success if the block visually overlaps the target outline.

frame_3.now_evidence: first stable contact and alignment cue visible
frame_3.predicts_next: push actuation expected; confirms goal direction

task_instruction: The task requires pushing a T-shaped block (gray) to a fixed target (green) with a circular end-effector (blue). Both observation and control frequencies are 10Hz.

node_specs.description: Raster scan to locate the T-block.
Move above block with a small clearance.
Close in and align to block edge.
Short leftward push; repeated three times.
Back off to a safe standoff.

failure_modes: Perception fails to detect block or target
Insufficient push distance due to friction
Robot collides with block corner at wrong yaw
recovery_strategy: Use repeated short pushes via Repeat to overcome stiction
Retreat and re-approach if contact is off-axis
assumptions: Frames show a red T-block and a blue target outline; instruction mentions gray block and green target—frames take precedence.
Push direction chosen as 180° (leftward) based on visual cue of right-side contact.
Three short pushes approximate continuous push due to controller discretization at 10 Hz.

expected_success_criteria: Final block pose visually overlaps the target outline
No loss of contact during push cycles
Robot ends in retreat pose without collision
